Context:
Program Name: Mechanical Engineering Technology – Design
Code: T121
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,203.00
International Tuition: $18,251.00
Method of Study: Full-time
Centre: Construction & Engineering Technologies
School: Mechanical Engineering Technologies
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Program Description: Solid grounding in engineering sciences and practical hands-on experience in mechanical and computer-assisted design labs.
Program Overview: Study real-world solutions in industries such as automotive, aerospace, robotics, biotechnology, and energy. In the third year, work with a team to plan, fabricate, and test designs for projects like medical devices, entertainment equipment, solar-powered products, and automotive accessories.
Availability: Fall 2024 (Domestic: Open, International: Open)
Winter 2025 (Domestic: Open, International: Opens Apr 8, 2024)
Spring 2025 (Not Available for both Domestic and International students)
Related Programs: Electromechanical Engineering Technician (T146), Mechanical Technician – CNC and Precision Machining (T173), Electromechanical Engineering Technology – Building Automation (T171)

Context:
The text provides information about an automotive accessories experience program offered by the college. This program includes lessons in teamwork and strengthens mechanical engineering knowledge and skills. Students have the opportunity for industry-driven applied research projects. There are specific semesters and courses mentioned, including:

Semester 1:
- Circuit Analysis (EMNG 1001)
- Introduction to Mechanical Engineering Design (MENG 1044)
- Machining Fundamentals and Metrology (MENG 1045)
- Occupational Health and Safety (MENG 1088)
- Personal Finance (GSSC 1027)
- Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1 (MATH 1160)
- Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000)

Semester 2:
- Introduction to CNC (CADE 1004)
- Engineering Physics (EMNG 1003)
- Introduction to Mechanical CAD (MENG 1026)
- Precision Machining (MENG 1090)
- Pneumatic Systems (MENG 2008)
- Mathematics for Engineering Technology 2 (MATH 1171)
- General Education Elective (GNED)

Semester 3:
- Advanced Mechanical CAD (CADE 2003)
- Jig and Fixture Design (DRFT 1014)
- Electronic Devices (EMNG 1013)
- Electro-Pneumatic Controls (MENG 2010)
- Statics (MENG 2039)
- Calculus 1 (MATH 2015)

Semester 4:
- Tool Design (DRFT 2024)
- Fluid Mechanics (MENG 1019)
- Engineering Strengths of Materials (MENG 2040)
- Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerance (MENG 2047)
- Product Development Engineering (MENG 2049)
- Industrial Automation: PLC Systems (MENG 3009)
- Calculus 2 (MATH 3006)

Semester 5:
- Thermodynamics (MENG 3006)
- Capstone Project 1 (MENG 3008)
- Finite Element Analysis (MENG 3012)
- Engineering Dynamics (MENG 3012)
- Machine Design 1 (MENG 3023)

Students who enroll in the program in January must complete semester 2 during the summer months (May to August). No specific emails or names were mentioned in the text.

Context:
Program Offered: Engineering (MENG) and General Education (GNED)
Semesters: Semester 6
Courses: MENG 3023 - Engineering Dynamics, MENG 3024 - Machine Design 1, MENG 3026 - Engineering Materials, MENG 3027 - Building Automation, MENG 3010 - Capstone Project 2, MENG 3025 - Machine Design 2, EMNG 2040 - Workplace Preparedness and Technical Report Writing, EMNG 2041 - Robotics, EMNG 3016 - Fundamentals of HVAC/R Systems
General Education Electives: Not mentioned in the text
Additional Courses: COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) (Before progressing to COMM 2000)
Placement Test Result: Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000
Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Communicate clearly and concisely in written, graphic and oral form using appropriate formal and informal vocabulary and formats.
2. Display appropriate responsible attitudes.
3. Carry out established design procedures, making use of handbooks, catalogues, specifications and codes.
4. Prepare and interpret detail drawings, assembly drawings and compile technical specifications.
5. Inspect, conduct tests and compare and compile data in accordance with standard formats and procedures.
6. Assist in the planning, operation, control and improvement of manufacturing and production processes.
7. Participate in the installation and maintenance of equipment and systems.
Tuition & Fees:
1. Domestic Tuition (for first two semesters): $4,203.00 *
2. International Tuition (for first two semesters): $18,251.00 **
Additional Costs: Estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 or Fall 2024. Fees are subject to change. Tuition fees are not included.

* Amounts listed are for programs starting in Fall 2023
** Amounts listed are for programs starting in Fall 2024

Context:
The text provides information on various fees and requirements for students at George Brown College. Here are the key factual points extracted from the text:

1. Fees: The text mentions that service and ancillary fees are estimated based on prior years, but subject to change without notice. It is important to note that these fees do not include books, which must be purchased separately by students. There is no specific mention of any fees related to the program offered.
2. Safety Equipment: Students are responsible for purchasing CSA standard safety shoes and prescription safety glasses if needed, as they are not provided by the college.
3. Financial Assistance: This program is approved for OSAP (Ontario Student Assistance Program) funding, but students must meet eligibility criteria.
4. Admission Requirements: To be eligible for admission, applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with a grade 12 English (C or U) and grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math, or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits.
5. Course Exemptions: College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions. Students can check the Transfer Guide for more information.
6. International Students: They should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page and International Admissions page for more information regarding country-specific admission requirements and how to apply. International students must apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
7. Contact Information: The School of Mechanical Engineering Technologies can be contacted at 416-415-5000, ext. 4365 or via email at engineeringtech@georgebrown.ca. Their office hours are from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., room D305. For general information about the college, contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002. Students can also contact international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin for virtual meetings or by submitting an application.
